question: If anyone finds this, then I guess my plan didn't work and I'm already dead... But if I can just go back to the beginning of all this, I still might be able to save her.
answer: Okay, okay... what now?

question: We're gonna be late again.
answer: When did you ever care about getting to school on time?

question: We're putting up pictures for Parent's Night. Righty-tighty, lefty-lucy.
answer: Thanks. Don't worry Evan, you'll have plenty of time. Darn it!

question: Um... can dad come this time?
answer: You know the answer to that.

question: Can't he come out for one day?
answer: We've been over this a hundred times. It's too dangerous for him.

question: But Lenny said that his dad's coming... and Tommy and Kayleigh's dad...
answer: Here, Ev... Finish this up for me.

question: All the dads are gonna be there.
answer: I get the point, kiddo. But I'm not so bad, am I?

question: No.
answer: Good. Because I've been waiting to see your art projects all week and I'd feel terrible if all you thought about was your father not being there.

question: Done. Try it.
answer: You're amazing, kiddo. Okay have a great day I love you I'll pick you up later gotta go...

question: You're amazing, kiddo. Okay have a great day I love you I'll pick you up later gotta go...
answer: Mrs. Treborn! I need to speak with you!

question: I'm sorry, but can it wait til tonight? I'm already late for work --
answer: I think you really need to see this. TOMMY! LEAVE LENNY ALONE! DON'T MAKE ME SEND YOU TO MR. VOYTEK'S OFFICE! I was going to show this to the principal, but I wanted to talk to you first.

question: What is it?
answer: Yesterday I had all the children draw pictures of what they wanted to be when they grew up. Most of them made drawings of what their parents did, but this...

question: I don't understand... Evan did this? Thank you for showing it to me first. I'll... I'll take care of it. Can I have the picture?
answer: Of course. There is one more thing, Mrs. Treborn. And I feel bad for mentioning it...

question: What?
answer: When I asked Evan about his drawing, well, he didn't remember doing it.

question: Uh, tell you what, Evan. If it's okay with your mother, I'd like to run some tests. Nothing scary. Okay, it might be a little scary...
answer: Just tell me that Evan doesn't have Jason's illness...

question: Look, Andrea, I'm sure he'll test negative for brain disorders. But there's something else you can try to monitor his memory.
answer: Anything.

question: A journal. Just have him write down everything he does.
answer: Why? What for?

question: Thanks, George. I really appreciate you watching him, he won't be any trouble at all.
answer: These'll bring you luck, Crockett.

question: Great. I'll see you soon. Evan? Evan? What are you doing with that knife?
answer: What happened?

question: Honey. What were you doing with that?
answer: I... I don't remember.

question: Evan, guess what? Dad got a new video camera and we're all gonna be in a movie.
answer: I don't think Evan gets to be in it --

question: Quit it, Tommy. Evan gets to be Robin Hood. I'm gonna be Maid Marian, and you're the Sheriff of Nottingham!
answer: I thought I was the bad guy!

question: Shut up, moron. Now get in your costume, Evan. And you have to promise, your bestest super-duper promise, that this will be our little secret. Think you can do that?
answer: Where am I? What happened? Where did we all go?

question: Calm down, kid. Stand still.
answer: I was just somewhere else -- how did I get here?

question: Quit acting like some retard or I'll call your mother and tell her what a naughty little shit you've been.
answer: Kayleigh? What happened? What's wrong with me?

question: Well, the good news is that the results are negative. I've found no evidence in the way of lesions, hemorrhaging, tumors...
answer: And the bad news?

question: Unfortunately, we've got nothing to work with. It's harder playing detective now.
answer: But you must have something to go on?

question: If I had to guess, I'd say the blackouts are stress related.
answer: But he's seven. What kind of stress can he have?

question: Plenty. Who knows? Maybe he's got severe coping problems about not having a father. Did you say the last blackout occurred when he was with his friend's dad.
answer: Come on, I doubt the answer's that simple.

question: You'd be surprised how often they are.
answer: Well, he has been pushing me to meet his father, but I've been putting it off.

question: It's worth a shot. I can arrange a controlled meeting. A careful dose of sedatives for Jason, some security, you and I monitoring. Evan comes in for a quick visit and with any luck, no more missing father complex.
answer: How soon?...

question: What happened, Evan? The truth.
answer: I don't know... I don't remember.

question: Something must've happened! What set him off?
answer: I... I blacked out.

question: With every breath you exhale, you can feel all of the tension draining from your body like water through a faucet. Nine, ten, and you're completely asleep. Relaxed. Now I want you to go back to the time you were in the woods with Lenny. Think of it like a movie. You can pause, rewind, or slow down any details you wish. Understand?
answer: Yes.

question: Where are you now?
answer: I'm standing next to Kayleigh, my hands are over her ears.

question: Are you hurting her?
answer: No, protecting her.

question: Okay. Then go a little forward in time. What do you see now?
answer: I see a car.

question: Yes, tell me about the car. Go on. Nothing can hurt you. Remember, this is only a movie. You're completely safe.
answer: I can't... the car vanishes and all of a sudden I'm on the ground in the woods.

question: The car doesn't vanish Evan. The movie in your head has broken, that's all. But now I've re-spliced it and I want you to tell me about the car.
answer: It's coming... argh! I can't!

question: Fight it Evan. Hurry. It's coming! Okay, Evan. Listen to my voice! On the count of ten, you're going to wake up. Feeling refreshed and remembering everything we talked about.
answer: What's happening to him?? Make it stop!

question: One. You're feeling more awake now. Two, your eyes no longer feel heavy. Five. Six. Refreshed and awake! Seven, eight. Come on, Evan, wake up, dammit!
answer: Evan wake up, oh please wake up!

question: Would someone just tell me already what the hell happened in the mailbox?
answer: Don't ever bring that shit up again. Not ever. Not to me, not to Kayleigh, or even Lenny. The stupid fuck if he ever learns to talk again. Understand? Ever. She don't want to talk about it, anyway. Do you Kayleigh?

question: Are you okay?
answer: There it is. Let's go. Holy shit! Look at that fat fuck! You'd have to wipe his ass with a forklift! Shut up, faggot. No one's talking to you!

question: I'm sorry Kayleigh. This was a bad idea.
answer: You really don't remember anything that happened? You're so lucky.

question: It's going to be okay. Lenny'll be fine. You'll see.
answer: Ouch.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: It's not your fault. Mrs. Kagan called dad and blamed us for what happened to Lenny.

question: Damn. Your dad did this?
answer: I deserve a lot worse.

question: So how was the movie?
answer: Okay.

question: Any exploding mailboxes?
answer: What do you mean?

question: I can't believe Tommy's still pissed at me. He knows I'm moving away, right?
answer: He's been acting real strange lately. He won't even look me in the eyes anymore.

question: Duck, here they come.
answer: Did your mom say if Lenny was... okay?

question: He must be. They're letting him go, right? Welcome home, Lenny! Sorry? Welcome home. Thought you might like some fresh air for a change.
answer: Hi, Lenny.

question: Crockett!!
answer: Look what you made me do!

question: What's wrong with you?! Kayleigh! Wake up!
answer: Why don't you fucking kiss her, Prince Charming!

question: Hey, I got no choice. Whoa. Smells like patchouli and... ass.
answer: Cricket, meet my well-mannered roommate, Evan.

question: Nice to meet you, too.
answer: Here, bro. Found your T-shirt.

question: Get dressed, Thumper, you're taking me out for my birthday.
answer: I thought you were a December baby.

question: This is bigger. Seven years to the day. No blackouts.
answer: Let's do this. Worms, plural. Talk to him about it, he's got the fetish.

question: Smells like sex in here.
answer: Thumper had a busy afternoon.

question: You're kidding. He's so... big.
answer: Charisma and eyeliner go a long way, I guess. Wanna beer?

question: Most guys tuck their porn under here, but all you have are... comp books.
answer: Yeah. I've been keeping journals since I was seven.

question: Wow... read something.
answer: No way, I'd be too embarrassed.

question: Then keep drinking, worm-boy. You're too uptight.
answer: Freeze! No "worm-boy". No "Mr. Worm," and no "Worm-Master-General!" Once you get a nickname like that you can't shake it. And I don't want everyone thinking I've got tapeworms coming out of my ass or something, okay?

question: Deal. Now read me something.
answer: For courage. It's like my mind refused to believe what it was seeing. Hearing Crockett make those awful screams... Just writing about it gives me the shivers.

question: Come on, go on...
answer: It was like Tommy was possessed or something. There was a hate in his eyes that I couldn't really call human. What the hell is going on?

question: Oh my God! No! No!
answer: Wake up, idiot. It was just a dream.

question: It didn't feel like a dream.
answer: Maybe because they never do. So Don Juan, you pass out on all your dates?

question: Hey, uh, it's me. Evan. What's that you're working on? A model? Well, you look busy, so maybe I should make this quick. I'd totally understand if you didn't want to get into this right now, but that day at the junkyard, could you help me remember what happened? Any details?
answer: I couldn't cut the rope.

question: Yeah, good, what else do you remember?
answer: Drop it or I'll slit your mother's throat in her sleep.

question: Jesus Christ. It really happened. What if I can get back all my lost memories with my journals.
answer: Make one peep and I swear it'll be your last, motherfucker.

question: Yes, hello, uh, Mrs. Kagan, this is Evan Treborn. I know. I'm sorry about that. But I really need to speak with him.
answer: Whoa! Didn't mean to scare you, Evan. Just wanted to know how the flatworms project was coming.

question: Oh, fine I guess. It's been kind of crazy lately with my mom coming up, so I haven't...
answer: I know, I know. Who can think of worms when your libido's in full swing, right? Just don't drop the ball, okay?

question: I won't let you down, Professor Carter. Please, mom. People will talk.
answer: I can't help it. I'm just so proud of you. You've got the highest grades in all of your classes.

question: Did Da -- Jason --- get good grades?
answer: Please. He got straight A's without ever touching a book. That was the one area where his memory never failed him.

question: Ma? Did he ever say that he figured out a way to recall a lost memory years after he blacked it out for the first time?
answer: Why do you ask?

question: No, it's just weird with him being such a brain and all, I just wondered if he was ever able to remember stuff he'd forgotten.
answer: When he was around your age... almost exactly your age. He said he figured out a trick to remember the past. I couldn't tell if they were real memories or just phantoms. You know, he might only have thought he actually remembered them...

question: Sure...
answer: And then, just before it got so bad that he had to be committed, he said that he could...

question: What? What could he do?
answer: Forget it. It's nothing. He was far too sick by then.

question: I never wanted to be in the movie anyway and it was cold so I wanted to wear my clothes but Mr. Miller took his shirt off --
answer: What the fuck are you doing?

question: Shhh! I need quiet for this.
answer: Are you stupid or what?

question: What?
answer: Shucks, I dunno. But maybe there's a reason why you've repressed the one day when some old lecher had you in your tighty whities, dammit! Yeah, man. I'd think twice about this. You could wake up a lot more fucked up than you are now.

question: God, Evan! I never thought I'd see you again. How've you been?
answer: Oh, comme si, comme ca, you know...

question: No, Evan. I don't know. It's been a long time. Fill me in.
answer: I'm going to State now. Things are going okay. I guess. Mom's good... Not since we were kids.

question: I've stopped a hundred times.
answer: So how's Tommy?

question: They kept him in juvy for a few years. Now he works over at Dale's Autobody.
answer: You still live with your dad?

question: No. I emancipated myself when I was fifteen.
answer: Wow. That must've taken some courage.

question: Not if you remember my dad.
answer: Couldn't you have moved in with your mom?

question: She had a new family. Not enough space for me. Said I should have moved in with her when we were kids. But... whatever.
answer: Actually, Kayleigh, the reason I came back to town was to talk to you.

question: Me? Are you kidding? Why?
answer: Remember when I was a kid I had all these blackouts?

question: Of course.
answer: Well, lately some of the memories have begun to come back and I'd kinda like to talk to you about one of them in particular. It'd be a big help.

question: Well, sure. I'll try to remember. Shoot.
answer: When we were kids. Your dad was making a movie. Robin Hood or something?

question: What do you want to know, Evan?
answer: It's just... did he... what happened in the basement?

question: It was a long time ago.
answer: I know, but...

question: Is that why you came all the way back? To ask a lot of stupid questions about Robin Hood?
answer: No, but I think something really bad might've happened to us.

question: Is there a point to any of this?
answer: Whatever happened, it wasn't our fault. You know we couldn't have stopped it. Look, Kayleigh. This may sound like bullshit coming from a guy who hasn't spoken to you in seven years... But you were seven years old and there's nothing you could've done to deserve...

question: Just shut up, Evan. You're wasting your breath.
answer: You can't hate yourself just because your dad's a twisted freak.

question: You're gonna see my fist in about two seconds unless you do what I tell you. Now in this part of the story, Robin Hood just married Maid Marian and they have to kiss and stuff like grown-ups do. So take your clothes off Kayleigh. Come on, like when you take a bath. Don't make a deal out of it. You too, Evan. Let's go.
answer: What time is it?

question: It's time for you to stand where the hell I told you.
answer: Wrong answer, fuckbag. This is the very moment of your reckoning. In the next thirty seconds you're going to open one of two doors. The first door will forever traumatize your own flesh and blood.

question: What's happened to -- How are you doing that?
answer: It'll change your daughter from a beautiful child into an empty shell whose only concept of trust was betrayed by her own sick pedophile father. Ultimately, it'll lead to her suicide. Nice work, daddy.

question: Who -- who are you?
answer: Let's just say you're being closely watched, George. Your other option is to get your porn off the rack and treat Kayleigh like... oh, let's say like how a loving father treats his daughter. Sound okay to you, Papa?

question: ...yes.
answer: Listen close then, fuckbag. You screw up again and I swear I'll flat out castrate you. One last thing.

question: I'm cold. And I'm putting on my clothes.
answer: What you need to do is discipline your son Tommy, because the kid's one sadistic pup.

question: Honey, are you all right? Oh my God, Evan. You're bleeding! Look at you!
answer: Jesus, Kayleigh, you're... Incredible.

question: Mmmm... You give good compliment. Clean up and come back to bed.
answer: Where... where are my clothes?

question: Those are your clothes, silly.
answer: This is too amazing! Un-fucking-real! Whoops. Sorry. My bad. Hey, you were with those assholes who threw popcorn at Thumper. And your name is... Gwen! Hey, uh, don't go freaking out on me over this, but do you remember when your dad first got his video camera?

question: Well I remember he had one... but he, like, put it away after the first day. Why would that freak me out?
answer: I dunno. Just being weird.

question: Such a goofus. See you tonight.
answer: Come on, Mom, be there! Hi, Mom and, uh, Chuck. Just calling to say hi and well, call me. Thumper! What time is it, man?

question: Remember, everyone! Only two weeks until your science projects are due.
answer: I still owe you an essay from last week. Is there any way I could get an extension?

question: And you are...?
answer: Evan Treborn.

question: The answer's 'no', Mr. Treborn. Now take a seat. The exam's about to begin.
answer: Leave me alone, asshole. I didn't lay a hand on you, okay?

question: Leave me alone, asshole. I didn't lay a hand on you, okay?
answer: Evan, you're hysterical. You study for this?

question: We'll find out soon enough.
answer: Me neither.

question: You're kidding. Are these the answers?!
answer: Damn, Evan, on the D.L.

question: Thanks. Wow. Hey, I want to do something really special for Kayleigh tomorrow. If I said I needed some help from you and the brothers...
answer: I'd say blow me. Get the pledges to do it.

question: Oh my God, that was good. Where'd you learn all those new tricks?
answer: So it didn't feel... weird?

question: Yeah, if you call multiple orgasms weird.
answer: Yellow.

question: Fuck 'em.
answer: What do you think it is about us that makes us so perfect? Like, looking back, whatever gave you the nerve to sneak out and visit me after I moved away?

question: As if my dad could've stopped me from seeing you. What's he gonna do to me?
answer: You think we'll always be together?

question: That is the plan, right? Hell or high water?
answer: Just making sure. Order, order. So all you rushes know what you've got to do for me? Pledges, rushees, same difference. Now this is a one-time deal. You do all this for me and I'll never give you shit again. Promise.

question: I don't understand, where are you taking me?
answer: You'll see.

question: I don't know what to say. It's beautiful.
answer: Go on. Sit down.

question: Why are you doing all this for me?
answer: Simple math. When I woke up this morning and saw your smile... I knew that I wanted to spend the rest of my life with you.

question: Simple math. When I woke up this morning and saw your smile... I knew that I wanted to spend the rest of my life with you.
answer: We been lookin' all over for you, man.

question: Did you see who did this? You see anyone?
answer: Probably them Pika fuckers.

question: How could he get away with this? Right in front of the goddamn frat house!
answer: Don't. He's probably watching. It's my fault. I should have told you he was released a few weeks ago.

question: Might'a been nice. Like this is gonna do any good. Maybe one of the frat guys has a gun.
answer: Please, Evan. Don't even joke. He wouldn't hurt you. He's just trying to scare you away from me.

question: Yeah, right. Tell that to Crockett.
answer: It's not his fault, Evan. You knew how bad he had it when we were kids.

question: Don't give me this Oprah-book club bad upbringing shit, because you turned out fine.
answer: My father never laid a hand on me. It's like the prick saved it all up for Tommy.

question: Fine, then. We'll let campus security deal with him.
answer: Are you okay?

question: What do you mean?
answer: It's just... you've been acting kinda strange, you know?

question: Like how?
answer: I don't know. You seem... different. You make weird jokes. Your accents changed. You don't even walk the same.

question: I walk differently?
answer: I can't put my finger on it, but everything's a bit off. Even the dinner tonight. It was beautiful, but...

question: I know I've been actin strange lately. It's just that... I don't want anything to happen to us.
answer: Wait. Something's not right. Isn't that your jacket?

question: What?
answer: Tommy.

question: Aw, hey now, that was a compliment.
answer: What the hell are you doing?

question: It wasn't enough that the whole world loves you, but you had to take away the last person on earth who didn't think I was a piece of shit.
answer: No one thinks you're a piece of shit, Tommy.

question: ...I spoke to your new lawyer about the appeal. He's sure he can get you off on self-defense, so if you're patient.
answer: How long will I be in here?

question: I don't know. These things take time.
answer: How's Kayleigh doing? She all right? What about my journals, Mom? Did you bring the ones I asked for?

question: I found these. The others are still in storage.
answer: Damn it, Mom. I told you I need them all!

question: Fine. You'll get them, Evan. But I think it's far more important to focus on your case right now.
answer: Sure, Mom. You're right. Just try to tell Kayleigh I'm sorry.

question: I'm not gonna lose you, kiddo. Promise me you'll hang on, Ev.
answer: Let go! They're mine! Motherfucker! You're religious Carlos, you believe that bit about "the Lord works in mysterious ways?"

question: Let go! They're mine! Motherfucker! You're religious Carlos, you believe that bit about "the Lord works in mysterious ways?"
answer: Straight up.

question: Because I think he sent me to your cell on purpose. For you to help me.
answer: Shit. I knew you were crazy.

question: I ain't bullshitting. Jesus speaks to me in my dreams. Pack of smokes says I can prove it to you. So when I'm out, I need you to watch my face and hands closely.
answer: You need to see the prison shrink, man.

question: Anything today? Just tell me if anything weird happens.
answer: Weirder than this?

question: Oh, Mrs. Boswelllllllll?
answer: Oh sweet Jesus. It's true. It's a miracle! A miracle! Your hands. The stigmata!

question: What did you see? What did it look like?
answer: Signs of the Lord. They just appeared out of nowhere. I thought you were loco!

question: He's saying it's like forty years worth of new memories have been jammed in my brain since last year. Overload city. 'Sat about the gist of it, doc? Mind if I wait in the car? The lighting here bugs my eyes. Well, it's nice seeing you again. But you know, people to see, things to read... Is there anything you need? Anything I can get you? What about the models, man? Bet I can get you a shitload of models up in here. Okay, Lenny. Just wanted to say "hi".
answer: You knew the whole time, didn't you? When you put the blade in my hand, you knew something big was going to happen. Didn't you?!

question: Y... yes. I guess I did.
answer: Then you should be where I am. You should be where I am.

question: Today I get to meet my father. His name is Jason and he is crazy...
answer: Are you okay? You looked like you were somewhere else for a second there.

question: Look, Jason, I need some fast answers if I'm ever gonna fix what I've done.
answer: I was praying this curse would have ended with me.

question: But it didn't. And now I need info to make things right again and you're the only one who can give it to me.
answer: There is no "right". When you change who people are, you destroy who they were.

question: Who's to say you can't make things better?
answer: You can't play God, son. It must end with me. Just by being here, you may be killing your mother.

question: Good guess, fuckbag. Remember me now? We had a great chat once when I was seven. One question, fuckbag. Where can I find your daughter?
answer: Oh, I thought you were my eight o'clock. Make it fast, I'm expecting someone.

question: Nice to see you, too. Can I come in?
answer: If I knew you were coming I'd have cleaned the stains off the sheets. What do you want?

question: I just needed to see... a friendly face.
answer: Well, time is money, Evan. So you... Well, I guess I can spare ten minutes for an old friend, right? So how's tricks? Sorry, occupational humor.

question: I get it. You can drop it now.
answer: Oh, I'm sorry. Does my line of work make you uncomfortable, precious?

question: No. Just that you need to hurt me with it. I've been where you've been.
answer: Ha! Where's that?

question: The bottom. When you're just a piece of meat waiting for the next attack.
answer: What's happened to you?

question: You wouldn't believe me. I mean, people always say, "You wouldn't believe me", but in this case, it's not even worth trying.
answer: I've seen some sickening shit. I don't blink twice anymore, especially in your case.

question: Why's that?
answer: Because you're... different.

question: Different? How?
answer: Let me ask you a question. Just a little one that's been gnawing at me for years.

question: Yeah?
answer: On the bridge. How did you know that Tommy had your dog? That was no fucking hunch.

question: Do you remember when I was a kid and I had those blackouts?
answer: You're right, Evan, I don't believe you.

question: I never thought you would. That's why I've never bothered to tell a soul until now, and why I never will again.
answer: I'm the only person you've told? That's a great line. Does that make other girls swoon? Do they actually eat up this bullshit?

question: I couldn't give a shit if you believe me or not, and frankly I'm too tired to prove it to you.
answer: Oh? There's proof now?

question: Shit. I dunno. How would I know about the twin moles on your inner thigh?
answer: Anyone with fifty bucks could tell you that.

question: Then forget that. How about... you prefer the smell of a skunk to flowers, you hate cilantro because for reasons unknown to you, it reminds you of your step-sister. Oh! And when you orgasm, your toes go numb. I'm sure your clientele aren't privy to that one. I just thought you should know.
answer: Know what?

question: That I didn't leave you there to rot.
answer: There's one major hole in your story.

question: Which is?
answer: There is no fuckin' way on this planet or any other that I was in some fuckin' sorority. Sure you don't want your wallet?

question: Don't think I'll need it where I'm going.
answer: Off to change everyone's life again, is that it? Maybe this time you'll pop up in some mansion while I wind up in Tijuana doing the donkey act.

question: I'm over it. Whenever I try to help anyone it all turns to shit.
answer: Well, don't give up now, Slick. You've already done so much for me. Hell, why don't you go back in time and save Mrs. Halpern and her baby. Then maybe Lenny wouldn't freak out and ruin my family. Oh, here's one! Go back when I'm seven and fuck me in front of Daddy's handicam, you know, straighten me out a bit...

question: Forget it. What's the point of Psych now? Tomorrow I could wake up as some dirt farmer in Bangladesh.
answer: Let's go for a stroll.

question: So Tommy's really into this Jesus kick, huh?
answer: You know how spiritual he's gotten ever since he saved Mrs. Halpern and Katie.

question: He saved Mrs. Halpern? Please, the twisted fuck.
answer: Is something the matter?

question: Yeah, I think I gotta get these fixed or something. Kayleigh? Do you ever think about "us?" I mean, wonder if it could ever have been different between the two of us?
answer: Sure, Evan, why not? You were the first person I really ever cared about.

question: I was?
answer: That's why when I was little I never went to live with my mother.

question: I don't get it.
answer: When my folks split, they gave me and Tommy a choice who we wanted to live with. I couldn't stand my dad, but I knew if I moved to my mom's I'd never see you again.

question: I never knew that. So then you still sometimes think of us... together?
answer: It's crossed my mind from time to time.

question: And...?
answer: Well a lot of things cross my mind. I've always been a fast thinker, Ev. I can play out the movie of our entire lives in under a second. Boom -- we fall in love -- get married -- two kids, your keen analytical insight matched to my generous nature -- kids grow old as do we, relatively stable relationships, matching burial plots, the whole bit. It took a lot longer to spit out than to imagine.

question: Then you think it might have worked out?
answer: Why not? But that's not how things wound up. I'm with Lenny, Lenny's your friend. And there it ends.

question: Would it make any difference if I told you that no one could possibly love anyone as much as I love you?
answer: You forgot to put the toaster on the edge.

question: But you, Kayleigh and Lenny like toast. And that's really all that matters now.
answer: I'll get you changed. Visiting hours are almost up.

question: You're. Acting. Like your father.
answer: Come on, Mom. Just 'cause Dad was my age when he started going crazy doesn't mean that I'm nuts.

question: How. Did you. Know that?
answer: You told me that on Parents' Weekend. Remember? Wait, that wasn't me. Or you.

question: Just. Like. Jason.
answer: Don't worry. I'm gonna get you out of here.

question: Are you sure you even packed it?
answer: My mom packed for me. I think she sent everything I ever owned. So we'll see.

question: Is this it? What do you need it for? I don't get you lately.
answer: Duly noted. Now I'm gonna ask you for one last favor.

question: What?
answer: Shhh. I need to concentrate on the blockbuster if I'm gonna destroy it.

question: Destroy it?
answer: If I hadn't blown my arms off, Mom never woulda started smoking in the first place. Now shhhh. Yes. Now how do I destroy the blockbuster?

question: Well, that didn't work...
answer: Now in this part of the story, Robin Hood just married Maid Marian and they have to kiss and stuff like grown-ups do.

question: Wait! I need my belt! Loo loo, skip to my loo. Loo loo, skip to my loo. Loo, loo, skip to my loo.
answer: Hey kid, don't bother with the belt.

question: Back off, fuckbag! Amazing. That word never fails to make an impression with you...
answer: Easy does it, Evan! Don't be a bad boy or I'll tell mommy you were naughty.

question: And I'll tell the Child Protective Services about your kiddie porn endeavors. One step closer and I'll shove this up your ass!
answer: That's dangerous! You could blow your hands off!

question: Been there, done that. Oh God, Kayleigh... Kayleigh... no! You can't die again! I won't let this happen. I won't! Where are they?!
answer: Hey, Evan. What's the big rush? We don't meet for another hour.

question: Where are my goddamn books?
answer: Books?

question: My journals! Where are they?
answer: It kills me to have to go through this again. There are no journals. There never were. It's part of this fantasy world your mind created to cope with the guilt of killing... Think Evan. You've invented a disease that doesn't exist. Alternate universes with colleges, prisons, paraplegia...

question: But I... I need those books.
answer: You remind me of your father. He always screamed for a photo album even though he never had one.

question: Photos?
answer: Jesus, no.
